title: 7 Healthy Habits From Japan - Goodnet
description: Practiced by the Japanese, these secrets may lead to a long and healthy life!
cleaned_text: What is the secret to living a long, healthy life? You might find the answer to this age-old question (pun intended) in Japan. The country has had the longest life expectancy in the world, with an average of 85.7 years, [ Business Insider](https://www.businessinsider.com/spain-worlds-longest-life-expectancy-2040-2018-10#:~:text=Japan%20has%20had%20the%20longest,life%20expectancy%20of%2085.8%20years.) reports. April 7 marks World Health Day 2021. The focus this year is on building a fairer, healthier world for everyone. This can start by bringing a healthy Japan right into your home! Discover the secrets to longevity from the Land of the Rising Sun with these [ healthy habits](/articles/7-best-kept-healthy-habits-from-far-east) from Japan. Food is thy medicine The term Blue Zone appeared in [ National Geographic](https://www.nationalgeographic.com/travel/destinations/asia/japan/uncover-the-secrets-of-longevity-in-this-japanese-village/), in an article on long life by Dan Buetter. Through his travels, Buetter identified five regions where people live the longest, including Okinawa, Japan. He said that, "There's an Okinawan phrase, nuchi gusui, which can translate as 'let food be your medicine.'" For Okinawans, that means plenty of fruits and vegetables with heart-healthy [ fish](/articles/7-smartest-brain-foods). Lifestyle choices like eating a nutritious diet impact health positively, resulting in living a long, healthy life, according to [ Healthline](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/food-as-medicine#disease-risk). Maintain strong family and social connections Humans are social creatures who thrive through connection. [ A 2017 study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5954612/) published in Innovation in Aging showed the positive impact that tight-knit families, and [ happy marriages](/articles/12-commandments-successful-lasting-happy-relationships) lead to better health and a longer life. Remember to spend quality time with family, whether it is the family you are born into, or the family you choose. This is maintained in Okinawa, according to National Geographic, where residents have a lifelong circle of friends called a moai that support each other well into old age. Drink plenty of tea In the west, people often reach for a coffee in the morning as their go-to beverage to start the day. But one of the best-kept [healthy habits](/articles/7-best-kept-healthy-habits-from-far-east) in the Far East is drinking [tea](/articles/5-teas-to-warm-up-your-winter-leave-you-feeling-healthy). Matcha, oolongcha, and ryokucha teas have remained a staple of the Japanese diet since ancient times, with amazing health benefits. A [ 2014 study](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4055352/) of Japanese adults found that those who drank green tea each day lowered their risk of diabetes by 33 percent. Take off your shoes when indoors Japanese traditionally do not wear their shoes in the house and change into slippers instead. It may seem strange at first. But when you think about it, it makes total sense! Shoes can carry infectious bacteria, according to [ Healthline](https://www.healthline.com/health/taking-off-your-shoes#risks), so consider taking off sneakers when indoors. After all, people wear their shoes in the dirty streets. The last thing you want to do is bring that all inside your home. Soak in long, hot baths Start the day with exercise When you want to start the day off on the right foot, take a lead from the Japanese and [ exercise](/articles/exercise-tips-for-active-retirees). Every morning, the Japanese traditionally participate in rajio taiso (radio exercise). According to [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jul/20/japan-love-mass-radio-exercise-rajio-taiso), it all started over 70 years ago when Emperor Hirohito started hosting a country-wide exercise broadcast to improve the health of Japanese soldiers. Today, the Japanese people continue the practice every morning, combining light movement such as bending, [stretching](/articles/study-finds-that-stretching-may-lower-blood-pressure), jumping, and toe touching. Live with purpose! You may have heard of [ hygge](/articles/danish-lifestyle-thats-taking-over-world) from Denmark or joie de vivre from France, but what about ikigai from Japan? The concept means "reason for being" and promotes having a [ purpose](/articles/generosity-leads-to-living-purpose) or direction in life. This results in more [satisfaction](/articles/optimism-may-be-secret-to-long-happy-life) and a longer life. Everyone has a purpose. You just have to know how to [find your passion](/articles/how-you-change-world-your-passion) in life.
